Question 1: Which of the following public health centers do First Referral Units (FRUs) and non-FRUs 
belong to?
questions.explanation:
First Referral Units (FRUs) and non-FRUs belong to the Community Health Centers (CHCs). The Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS) guidelines are a code of standards for uniformity in 
health facilities in the Indian public health system, under the National Health Mission (NHM), 
Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW), India. It aims to provide guidance on the 
infrastructure, human resources, drugs, diagnostics, equipment, quality, and governance 
requirements for delivering health services at all levels of facilities in the system. The 2022 edition of IPHS mainly concentrates on comprehensive primary health care, increasing 
the human workforce, decentralized access to healthcare, and better implementation of universal 
health coverage. 759

questions.question:
Question 2: A district has a population of 20 lakhs. According to the IPHS 2022 guidelines, approximately 
how many beds should the district public health system have for this population?
questions.explanation:
In a district having a population of 20 lakhs, the number of beds the district public health system 
should have is given as follows: 2000 essential and 4000 desirable. According to IPHS 2022 norms for the number of beds in district hospitals, 1 bed per 1000 
population is essential and 2 beds per thousand population would be desirable. Therefore, in a population of 20,00,000 the district public health system should have 2000 
essential and 4000 desirable beds. The essential number of beds should be achieved through the public health system of tertiary care 
(medical colleges), secondary care (DH, SDH, CHCs), and primary care in the district (PHCs and 
CHCs).

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following is not true about district and sub-district hospitals? 756 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: All districts need at least two district hospitals.
options.b: The minimum essential number of beds in a sub-district hospital is 100.
options.c: All districts do not need a sub-district hospital.
options.d: DNB training can be done in district hospitals.

questions.explanation:
Every district should have at least one comprehensively functioning district hospital (DH). District hospitals and subdistrict hospitals provide secondary care health services. Every district 
should have at least one comprehensively functioning DH. Districts with a population of less than 
5 lakhs and with a functional DH do not need a subdistrict hospital (SDH). Districts with a 
population of 5–10 lakhs can have one SDH. For a population of more than 10 lakhs, 1 SDH is 
needed for every 10 lakh population. The three pillars of district hospital services are providing clinical care, providing a knowledge 
hub for capacity development, and public health programs. Important functions of DHs: • Providing curative services • Palliative and rehabilitative services • Implementation of health programs • Drugs and diagnostic services • Administrative and other support services • Health promotion and prevention, education • Providing educational services, like Diplomate of National Board (DNB) training; training 
courses for healthcare professionals (HCPs) in auxiliary nursing and midwifery (ANM), 
telemedicine, and technology; and partnerships with universities

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Community Health Centers 
(CHCs)?

options.a: Non-FRU CHCs should have 50 essential beds.
options.b: Non-FRU CHCs can be located in urban areas.
options.c: FRU-CHCs can be located in rural areas.
options.d: Elective surgeries will not be performed at FRU-CHCs.

questions.explanation:
First Referral Unit - Community Health centers (FRU-CHCs) can be located in rural areas. Community health centers (CHC) can be classified into the following types: • Non-FRU-CHCs - They are located in rural areas. They provide preventive, promotive, palliative, 
and rehabilitative services. They also have curative services for normal delivery, stabilization of 761 
Sold by @itachibot common emergencies, etc. • FRU-CHCs are the first centers of referral from smaller centers such as sub-centers or primary 
health centers. They can be located in rural as well as urban areas. Apart from providing the 
abovementioned essential services, they also provide specialized services and elective surgeries. 
All the CHCs located in urban areas are FRU-CHCs. In addition to the above centers, CHCs called Block Health Public Units (BHPU) may be located in 
the block headquarters. Apart from clinical and public health services, they have a health 
management information system (HMIS). They also help in decentralizing health services.

questions.question:
Question 7: A rural hilly area has a population of 40,000. How many Primary Health Centers (PHCs) 
should it have?
questions.explanation:
A rural hilly area with a population of 40,000 should have 2 Primary Health Centers (PHCs). According to the latest IPHS 2022 guidelines, in hilly areas, there should be one PHC for every 
20,000 population. Since this village has a population of 40,000, it should have 2 PHCs.

questions.question:
Question 10: You are a medical officer in an Urban Health and Wellness Center (UHWC). The population 
of the place is 10,000. How many ASHA workers are needed for your UHWC?
questions.explanation:
In a place with a population of 10,000, 5 ASHA workers are needed. There are two forms of Health and Wellness Centers in Sub-Health Centers. • Health and Wellness Centre - Sub-Health Center (HWC-SHC) in rural areas: It requires 1 ASHA 
per 1000 population or 1 ASHA per habitation in hilly/tribal areas. It has a total staff of 3 + 
ASHAs. • Urban Health and Wellness Center (UHWC): It requires 1 ASHA per 2000 population and 1 
ANM per 10000 population. Health and wellness center- Sub-Center 1 ASHA per 1,000 
population or 1 ASHA per habitation in hilly/tribal areas. It has a total staff of 4 + ASHAs. Functions of HWCs under Sub-Health Centers: • Provide primary care services • Deliver the 12 packages under CPHC • Serve as a platform for teleconsultation and widening the range of diagnostics • Serve as a fulcrum for services in National Health Programmes 764 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: You are posted as a medical officer in a rural Health and Wellness Center - Primary Health 
Center (HWC-PHC). According to the IPHS 2022 guidelines, which of the following is 
incorrect regarding the essential manpower required for this PHC?
questions.explanation:
Specialists like ophthalmologists are not included as essential manpower for a PHC. Specialists for 
medicine, obstetrics & gynecology, pediatrics, ophthalmology, etc. are essential manpower 
included under polyclinics. According to the Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS) 2022 guidelines, a total of 12 staff is 
considered essential manpower for a PHC. They include 1 Medical Officer (MBBS), 2 staff 
nurses, 1 pharmacist, 1 health worker female/ANM, 1 health worker/health assistant (male), 
1 health assistant (female)/lady health visitor, 1 laboratory technician, 1 data entry operator, 1 
dresser, 1 accountant, and 1 sanitation staff. 765
